overview.problemStatement:
Forum

Let $g(n)$ be the maximal size of $A\subseteq \{1,\ldots,n\}$ such that the products $\prod_{n\in S}n$ are distinct for all $S\subseteq A$. Is it true that\[g(n) \leq \pi(n)+\pi(n^{1/2})+o\left(\frac{x^{1/2}}{\log n}\right)?\]



Erd\H{o}s proved \cite{Er66}\[g(n) \leq \pi(n)+O\left(\frac{x^{1/2}}{\log n}\right).\]This upper bound would be essentially best possible, since one could take $A$ to be all primes and squares of primes.

This was solved by Raghavan \cite{Ra25}, who proved that\[g(n) \leq \pi(n)+\pi(n^{1/2})+O(n^{5/12+o(1)}),\]and also that\[g(n) \geq \pi(n)+\pi(n^{1/2})+\pi(n^{1/3})/3-O(1).\]See also [786].




References


[Er66] Erd\H{o}s, P\'al, Remarks on number theory. {V}. {E}xtremal problems in number
theory. {II}. Mat. Lapok (1966), 135--155.

[Ra25] R. Raghavan, Sharp Bounds for Sets with Distinct Subset Products. arXiv:2501.02695 (2025).
